We had a picnic in the park. It was really odd because there were homeless junkies just sleeping on a mattress in the park there were also non looking homeless people just sleeping in the park...like oh I got tired let me just go to sleep in the grass. So weird.
The history in the park was amazing! The statues and the stories they told were awesome! Great learning experience for the kids it Boston seriously needs to clean up their parks.

Beautiful public park for walking and recreation while also a remarkable tribute and historic site marking the heart of the American Revolution and where Washington first took command of the revolutionary army. Special bonus is the new monument for the African American soldiers who fought and died in the revolution. So many aspects of this part of American history have been overlooked and underrepresented and this was a touching part of the park.

Although it was cold we enjoyed our time here during golden hour. Plenty to do, a safe one entry/exit fence hedged in climbing hydrangeas, large sandbox and stroller friendly throughout. Looks like there's an awesome water table feature and small splash pad for in-season park going as well. We also noticed many birds.

Tossing some toasted bread crumbs on Mac and cheese is not a substitute for seasoning. Not even a speck of salt on it.  Tasted very heavily of flour and not even cheese.   It's like they made a roux but forgot to add anything else.
Chicken tenders were good.
We enjoyed a candle light concert with an Adele repertoire. It was amazing!

Came here for an overnight trip with my son and his class. It's so peaceful here on Thompson Island, a nice break away from the city.  The staff are very nice and great with the kids. Definitely worth checking out if you have never been here.

I went there as a kid 13 years old.  I found it challenging but eye opening as a minority kid from mission Hill,  Roxbury.  I loved the learning, new environment they put us into,  the natural settings.  At the same time I was shocked by the biased treatment I received by the inner city minority kids I was with. Closed minds stay closed.
My favorite camp ever
An amazing place, I was really welcomed and I'm glad to visit this church!

We moved to Boston from the UK a year ago. We received a wonderful welcome at CRC and immediately felt it was a church family we could be part of. We enjoy the heart felt worship and bible centered teaching. The youth and children's ministries have also been a huge blessing.

A few years ago, I approached a tough roadblock in life that caused me to sought out God and reconnect with my long abandoned faith. As an androgynous lesbian, it's hard to find a church that won't judge me. After sitting in multiple worships and different churches, I found this one. At the time it was just Sunday worship in a Middle school in West Roxbury. Not only was worship held in a middle school auditorium, without glorious Christian decor, but no one dressed in their Sunday best. The longer I sat in that worship the more I realized this church accepts all, just like how God accepts all, no matter where you are, what you're dressed... he accept you for who you are.

Now the worship that first day, somehow I felt like it was drafted for me. Every word of the sermon and hymn sang, was exactly what I needed to hear. I cried the 75% of the worship.

It's been 4 years, they finally found an appropriate church building. Still minimalistic, but that's how it should be. Glad I'm still a member here.

My family and I started attending CRC last year during their outdoor services and never left. This church is filled with friendly people who are real and willing to share the ugly stuff about who they are, which gives me the freedom to do the same. It's a very caring and supportive community.  It is diverse, with solid biblical teaching, lively heart-felt worship, a strong focus on serving others, and lots of opportunities for people of all ages to connect outside of church. If you're looking for a church in Boston, I highly recommend  you check this one out.

I have been attending CRC for the past couple weeks and have absolutely LOVED every second of it!! Kevin and Josh have answered every single one of my questions, and there's been a lot of them, in great detail. The leaders of CRC pour themselves into both guests and members and focus on discipleship-making. Everyone is so kind and caring and looks after each other!! I'd highly recommend Charles River to anyone looking for a new church home!

I started attending this church about 7 months ago, and it instantly felt like home. The community in this church was so welcoming. They are on fire for Jesus and it shows by the way the love and serve the people of Boston. Coming from Texas the Bible Belt I wasn't sure what to expect but I felt the Lord more here in this small church that met in a Boston Public school than I ever did in Texas. If you're in Boston and looking for a church, should definitely give this one a shot.

As a college student, I have found this church to be incredibly awesome. We are often guilty of looking for a church that agrees with where we already stand, rather than a church that agrees wholly with the Bible. Charles River Church is the closest thing I have found to an authentic New Testament church. They strive to love the community and preach the Gospel faithfully. However, if you have never been to church, there is no need to be anxious, for the community is warm and welcoming. Everyone looks out for each other and genuine faith is producing an environment of love. You will find people who are following Christ's command of sacrificial love which is what our world could use a lot more of. This is definitely a place where you will can trust that they will preach the truth even when it is hard to take. If you decide to visit, you can be sure you will leave with more of God's word poured into your life.

I came to Charles River Church along with some friends my first year away at school and felt incredibly welcomed by everyone there. As a college student there are many ways to get involved serving with the church. For example, I've had the privilege of volunteering in the River Kids program during the worship gatherings. I've also had the opportunity to join in on some of the community outreaches like Kids Connect. I also found the church to be very hospitable to the students. They're great about connecting with us, whether it be through hosting us in their homes for lunch or organizing game nights- definitely a caring community.

Decent playground. The view wasn't what I expected, 3 lane road and tall buildings on one side and water front partially blocked by walking area on the other. Very noisy. It had a full impossible to open trash bin and some garbage around the playground itself. There are portable bathrooms nearby. Kids had a blast of course. Great place to chase pigeons, they just keep coming.

Great park for toddlers. Large climbing structure intended for little ones. Okay for larger kids. Two smaller connected structures with monkey bars. Toddlers can climb on the bigger structure for greater challenge. Really best for little ones. 4 bucket swings, one with extra large leg holes. 4 standard swings. There are also a few picnic tables.
Great playground has swings, super good monkey bars with multiple slides and places to run around and climb on.  A pole to slide down. Has portable bathrooms nearby and great views of the waterfront.
Clean, safe, lots of fun.  When I was there, kids from 1- about 7 were having a ball.  Everything is gated in, so no chasing down kids, just grab a bench, relax, and watch the kids have fun.

Gated park right next to the Science Museum. It was an absolute blast for my 2 year old and 4 year old, and there were some older kids there as well (maybe up to 6 or 7 years old). We walked over here after spending some time on the Esplanade and realizing that the playground over there was a bit much for our little kids.

One of my favorite playgrounds in the area. The gate separating the spray deck and the park is broken but you get over it.  If you have a runner, just be ready to have a soaking wet ride home.

There is parking available.  You can you access it from westbound side of Storrow drive. (You'll see the entrance directly after the park and spray deck. If you miss it, you have to get off and go around to try again...so don't miss it)

The entire thing is gated in by a locked gate that actually works. Even though it's on Storrow,  you've got to work pretty hard to get into any real danger.
It's a good park but the cars are so noisy. Too bad there's no screen. There are swings (for big and small kids) and a splash pad
Great place to play. The squirrels might take your lunch however if you leave it unattended or even set down your sandwich between bites. Nice fellow as otherwise.

I have been renting Kayaks from this place for some time and every time we kayak with them, it is fantastic! The price for one kayak for 1.5 hours is 30 dollars. You should definitely secure your reservation on their website beforehand if you want to save time when you get there to check in!
Fun weekend activity. We rented a canoe for four at this place. Staff was very friendly, weather couldn't be better. About $59 total for 1hr. I think you can rent a kayak for two for $25/hr

My in laws were visiting from out of town and wanted a fun easy activity near water. This was the perfect activity! If you are looking for a day on the water this is the perfect place for you. They are super organized, in a good location, have friendly staff. You can take how long you like on the river and the price isn't bad at all. They offer kayaking paddle boating canoeing and paddle boarding. Prices are $21 per person. No reservations required. On a busy weekend, the wait from the time you arrive until you get on the kayak is less than 15 min and there is plenty of street parking near by. I'd definitely go again!

A great bonding experience for you and your dog! 

The staff were very friendly and helped you along the way when picking out a kayak suited for your needs. I would definitely recommend filling out the waiver form before coming since it makes the process very quick and easy!

This was the first time my dog experienced going on a kayak and she was terrified out of her mind. Almost fell into the water a few times, but we managed! Well, at least she got to experience it for herself for once.

They offer dog life-jackets as well if you don't have any for your pet, which is pretty handy! 100% pet-friendly! Would recommend coming here again if you want to experience it with your fluffy friend.

Easy and fun!
I rented a double kayak and a paddle with friends and it was pretty fun. ( see prices on pictures) we lasted an 1.5h and the weather was amazing!
We came in without a reservation day of and we go it right away. ( just have to sign a waiver)
I definitely recommend.

I had fun. The water is gross but as long as you don't tip your boat or paddle so hard, it's fine. Be sure to wear sunscreen though. The staff was really friendly, especially the guy who fits you for lifejackets. He seemed like he's always in a good mood, who knows?
Had a Amazing time with my family. You have to go early to get the free parking specially week end or holidays. Stuff were very nice and friendly.
response_from_owner_text: Thanks so much for the review. glad you have a good time! also just for the future, there is a big lot further down on Soldiers Field Rd, so it's rare that there is no parking, just might be a further walk.

review_text: Easily the best scape you ll  have in a busy city. You can enjoy kayak by yourself or with your friends. You will be wearing a life jacket so all of you who don't know how to swim also can join in. This kayak takes you around Charles River in Boston along with MIT. Add to that it is a best way to exercise as well. This place also has really good restaurants near by so you can have a good lunch afterwards. The only down side is that it is only seasonal limited to summer. Other than that is it a must try.

Although the rooms are kept clean. They are small, grey, poorly furnished rooms with NO decor. To make matters worse, you are expected to shower with the other guests!!! The staff does a great job making you feel like you're in jail!
Very disappointed that there was no balcony as described. Still great views from my second story room.
The food is decent, and during the remainder of your stay you can enjoy tax-payer-provided healthcare, air conditioning, and all the Television you can watch.
I highly recommend and extended stay. At least a couple years to experience everything it has to offer. Great place to make friends.
Does not live up to my expectations as a river of mud
IT IS SOOOO NOT  MUDDY #thumbsup
WAYYY TOOOO MUDDDYYYYY! #thumbs down
Highly recommended

place_name: Paddle Boston : Blessing of the Bay, Somerville
review_text:
Great experience! My kids and I were able to have a unique little adventure on the water. We got to see swans, herons, geese, and other birds.

The staff was friendly, safety oriented, and able to answer all our questions. I would definitely do this again.

place_name: Paddle Boston : Blessing of the Bay, Somerville
review_text: Beautiful scenery. Lots of geese, swans and turtles. I walk around this area so it was great to see it from this point of view

place_name: Paddle Boston : Blessing of the Bay, Somerville
review_text: Great place. Quiet, very good for first timers on a kayak or cannoe!

place_name: Paddle Boston : Blessing of the Bay, Somerville
review_text: Amazing experience have a day off and paddle

place_name: Paddle Boston : Blessing of the Bay, Somerville
review_text: You can rent a canoe or kayak to go out on The Mystic River. A hidden out of the way gem.

place_name: Paddle Boston : Blessing of the Bay, Somerville
review_text: Wonderful for a family kayaking trip.  Crew was wonderful, helpful, friendly and courteous.  Water was cool, light breeze and sun was out.  Glad we all put on sunscreen.  Great Father's Day fun.  Highly recommend!

place_name: Paddle Boston : Blessing of the Bay, Somerville
review_text: I looove this company, been a member for years. This location features the same friendly and personable experience as you'd expect from every PB location. You can paddle the Mystic all the way to the beautiful lake upriver, or go past Assembly and up the Malden River, or if you have an air horn and a spray skirt you can go through the locks into the Inner Harbor. You can park at Assembly and take a nice walk along the river to the boathouse, or park nearby. Thanks!

place_name: Paddle Boston : Blessing of the Bay, Somerville
review_text:
The area itself is beautiful and a natural spot for kayaking. The guides who set you up seemed like college kids who were not overly concerned for your safety or maybe were not trained to go over what to look out for when on the water. Like the fact that local boaters will be driving full speed through the kayaking launch area to get the near by marina. Many local boaters were obnoxiously driving fast and close to kayakers. A heads up would've been nice!
They also do not keep track of which kayak you take out, or if you returned on time. As we returned the kayak we gave our name to the same girl that set us up. We said good night thank you and left around 6:30pm. I received a phone call at 9pm from the same girl who said she was looking for us and wasn't sure if we came back? Very strange but hope they read this and can close any safety gaps in how they train as well as take down peoples info.
response_from_owner_text: Thank you so much for your feedback, I will definitely follow up with our staff. It is a no wake zone so the big boats should not have been going to fast, I'm sorry that happened!

review_text:
The Speedway looks nice and should be nice, but I've had off-putting experiences each of the four times I've come here. I think the main problem is that the Speedway doesn't really operate like a standard food hall (e.g. Time Out Market or High Street Place) or like what you would expect for a 'beer garden plus food' sort of thing (e.g. some Trillium and Nightshift locations). In fact, they have a lot of rules that go against expectations.

For example it seems to be strictly 21+ even during the day, so if you happen to show up with kids, as my wife and I did with our 7 month old, you're out of luck. (Edit: I read on the Speedway's website that "THE SPEEDWAY IS ALL AGES, FAMILY-FRIENDLY VENUE WHERE SOME BUSINESSES BECOME 21+ AT 6PM." That's a good policy, but for whatever reason we were turned away at 3 PM for having a baby with us. So, I'm confused...)

There also seem to be a lot of rules about who can sit where and what food or drink you can bring from one sub-section of the place to another. Finally, the last time I went, most of the stalls either weren't open or were serving a limited range of pretty expensive food. I like the concept, I like Notch, and I want to like this place, but it has consistently rubbed me the wrong way.
response_from_owner_text:
Hi John,

Thank you for your feedback around your recent experience at The Speedway.

The Speedway is an all ages, family friendly venue where some businesses become 21+ at 6PM.  We're not "strictly 21+ even during the day."  Unfortunately, you visited us on the one day this year when Notch had a site-wide event called Forever Lager '24 that was 21+ and no dogs.  While Notch communicated that policy change on their website and event posts, we did not do a good job as The Speedway making that announcement on our website/events calendar. I'm sorry you had to find out when you arrived at the gate and spoke with our host. Please be assured that we will do a better job to communicate a policy change on our website, if one of our businesses were to have another event like this one.

Thank you for referencing the alcohol rules.  There are two liquor licenses at play here - The Speedway has a liquor license that extends to several businesses, and Notch has their own liquor license.  As a result, and due to ABCC rules, it's beer in the beer garden and wine, sake, cocktails on the patio.  We have recently improved our signage to make it easier to understand the two distinct areas.  Now and again, the premises rules change when a big event takes place, however, we have staff and signage in place to let people know where they can and can't take beer/alcohol during those times.

We hope you will give us another try this summer!

review_text: Was here on Friday for an Event/Party.  Great open space with lots of room to wander around.  Parking was close by everyone was very friendly.  Would recommend.
Great looking little spot! Noch brewery has some great beers! Can't wait to see some of the food venue they are putting in.

Love the space. And now that they've opened more restaurants the food is great too. I wish they had a few more bartenders at Notch to make the line move a little faster. And parking can be a challenge.

This is such a cool spot for local arts. Between the vendors at Garage B and the Cambridge Art Association's beautiful little gallery space - it's really the place to be! Definitely check out any Brighton Bazaar events here.
Great beer garden with a good selection of craft brews. Indoor seating is available. Bring your own food or order food from local shops.

BIKERS BEWARE
My bike was stolen when secured with a cable lock to one of the stands in the front of the parking lot. I'm sure this wasn't the first time. This place is great but needs to install cameras and more lighting

Wow what a cool place. And it's kind of tucked in there, so it seems exclusive. Absolutely love the CAA Gallery. Saw some amazing art that featured Boston. Love that. Also can have a beer and a haircut and buy some really cool products while I'm at it. Great place to hang with friends.
response_from_owner_text: Thank you Madeleine, CAA has also worked with Notch to have some incredible art in the tap room as well!

review_text:
Best experience ever for my son!
Great facility on the Charle's River, great coaches,  beautiful boats!
I thank you so much the great team of CRI for the amazing work with my son!
I would strongly recommend CRI to anyone.
response_from_owner_text: Thanks, Matilda! So glad they've have a great time at CRI.

review_text: From an Adult Rowing perspective, CRI must rank as one of the finest facilities and programs in the world. From the "Learn to Row" program to the Comp Teams, including Novice and Rec programs, plus a full boathouse with every kind of boat, CRI provides space for the head, the heart, and the hand. Teammates, Coaches, Maintenance and Admin staff are each skillful, thoughtful, and helpful. The 2nd-floor training facility rocks year-round - 75+ ergs, 30+ bikes, weight room, class room, and locker rooms. Regardless of age, skill level, physical abilities, or fitness, CRI is a place to learn and grow in the sport of rowing. Plus it's on the Charles River, home of the iconic Head of the Charles, where CRI teams practice! CRI - a gem hidden in plain sight.
Beautiful all times of the year, definitely a must for rowers of any skill level!

A sporting gem of greater Boston. A state of the art rowing center with a mission to promote inclusivenss, health, fitness and more. Unique programs like Military Veterans row for free, training pad for Olympians and regular enthusiasts and others. Definitely recommend checking it out.
Outstanding organization. Top notch staff and equipment.
response_from_owner_text: Thank you so much, Christopher!

review_text: Parents and teens appreciate CRI's full commitment  to developing young athletes and promoting team work and inclusivity. Their training programs are rigorous and the highest quality. This is an outstanding program!
Head long down and used CRI as a base for some training before HOCR. Great facilities and very one was friendly and helpful.
response_from_owner_text: Good luck this weekend, Will!

review_text:
I've been to lots of rowing clubs. This building is beautiful on the banks of the Charles.

We were boating from here for the head of the Charles Regatta. Despite being a very new boat house it blends right in with its surroundings. We were extremely well accommodated during our stay and use of the club.

The facilities are great.

- huge boat bays
- great erg room
- well set up weights room
- showering and changing facilities
Small but functional. Well maintained.
Great location. Beautiful facility. I went to Liz Chase's yoga class Sunday at 9:30.
Lot's of Zumba classes and other fitness classes and pool, fair fees and on hold charge
Buencervicioalcleente

place_name: Boating in Boston at Nahanton Park
review_text: Very peaceful and quiet boat experience. The parking can get tricky some days. Several options for different family sizes. Booking in advance recommended.

place_name: Boating in Boston at Nahanton Park
review_text: It's unfortunate that Paddle Boston isn't running this location anymore because whoever is doesn't allow two adults and two young kids (6 & 4) on one canoe. One kid running the check in wasn't even aware until the other kid lounging behind him nodded sluggishly "no" when I came up to ask for rental. This is a jalopy operation with beat up canoes stacked up. Nothing professional like the well run CRC&K (now Paddle Boston). Just lazy and nonsensical policies.
response_from_owner_text: Hi Jovan, we are sorry to hear you didn't have a good experience at our Nahanton Park Location. Our staff's first priority is safety which is why we always abide by the manufacturers listed max capacity in a boat. Feel free to send us an email and we'd be happy to give you a gift card for you to give us a second chance!

place_name: Boating in Boston at Nahanton Park
review_text: I love this place for kayaking. Very pleasant staff, check-in and checkout is easy. I kayaked in both directions and I found going towards Newton smoother than West Roxbury. However, I saw more wildlife going towards West Roxbury. Regardless, I enjoy kayaking along this part of the Charles and I highly recommended this location.

place_name: Boating in Boston at Nahanton Park
review_text: Shallow waters in many spots, relaxing day out, wildlife to observe, picnic tables to sit before and after to wind down. More popular location than a few others of Paddle Boston. During COVID, weekend reservations were starting to fill up three days before, whereas other locations are empty until the day before.

place_name: Boating in Boston at Nahanton Park
review_text: Great place for kayaking or canoeing. Peaceful and quiet lake. The staff was nice and helpful
response_from_owner_text: Ariel thanks so much for the kind words. Come on back

place_name: Boating in Boston at Nahanton Park
review_text: Lovely place to paddle. Staff are friendly and helpful, especially the man who checked me in (Tim I believe)). One short stretch is a more urban area, but other than that surrounded by nature and wildlife.

place_name: Boating in Boston at Nahanton Park
review_text: Loved being here it makes you feel like you're in the middle of wilderness but you're only 10 miles from downtown Boston!

place_name: Boating in Boston at Nahanton Park
review_text: Great place to rent kayaks. The staff is friendly and the paddle is pretty and mostly still water. You can also put your own kayak in here as well and use their dock. I've done that before when a friend is renting, but I brought my own.

I usually don't post such negative reviews but I have to share my opinion this time. The apartments look very nice, they are spacious, and although this complex is not cheap but reasonably priced in comparison to the other complexes In the area. The main issue is- There is no one talk to. You can't get a hold of a leasing person over the phone, you can't ask any questions because you won't get response, no one will ever get back to you. When we booked our tour and arrived to the complex, the front desk person knew nothing about the tour, and we communicated via text messages with some automatic system. After the tour there was one to answer questions. I'm seriously wondering, are you guys trying to save costs and eliminated all your employees at the leasing office? How is a person supposed to lease an apartment there when there is no human being to answer the phone? I can only imagine how you handle maintenance issues, will I also talk to an automatic messaging system?  No, thank you. Had to pass on this one.
response_from_owner_text:
Irene,
We are saddened to hear that you did not have a positive touring experience. All tours are self-guided and conducted by our centralized leasing consultants. They are available via text to answer questions and assist you with your tour while still allowing you to explore the community at your own pace. Our leasing is centralized to provide our residents with our onsite team's full attention. We apologize that you were dissatisfied with your experience and appreciate your feedback.
Kind Regards,
Madison

review_text: Pouring from upstairs more than hour but still no one came. The only person you "can" talk to is the outside answering service, and they will hang up on you if you are not patient enough to get an immediate help. No emergency maintenance person on site in a big building like this.

Kind Regards,
Madison

720-348-7620

review_text:
Extremely high rent - even higher than what you are initially told due being nickle and dimed. You will be charged additional fees for practically everything, and there are absolutely no utilities included in rent costs; not even a parking space - which gradually increase in price the more you rent out. If you pay your rent online (as of COVID-19, it is the only way to do this) you will be charged a "convenience fee" of nearly $100. The price is simply not worth it at all, and it will more than likely exceed $3000.

On top of this, recent new staff are not particularly welcoming or skilled. The front desk representatives will often times be on their phones, away for extended periods of time, or completely ignore or forget about you. This makes any trip to the front desk a hassle. It took nearly a month to complete all updated lease paperwork for a roommate change, because the employee in the leasing office did not reach out to us and made an error in one of the documents we needed to sign. Our old roommate is still on our lease because of it. Maintenance is exceptional most of the time, but if you need a new drawer in your kitchen or anything that might require a bit of money on their part, then forget about it. We've been trying to get a new kitchen drawer since we moved in 8 months ago.

To no fault of the building, the community is always very unwelcoming and entitled. There are many well-to-do folks of all ages who live in this building that are incredibly rude and think that the world revolves around them. If you take too long to hit the clicker for the garage, you'll be honked at. There are also many residents who do not clean up after their dogs, or those that think their dog is an angel and do not respect you or your own pet's space outside.

My girlfriend and I will be moving out at our earliest opportunity, and may even look into buying out our lease. While the apartments themselves are nice, they are not worth the extreme penny pinching, unprofessional staff, and unpleasant community. You can find a whole lot better.

I have been living here for 3 years now. Beautiful home, but staff up front is awful, they make it as if this is not your home.They are extremely rude to guest who are coming to visit you. Maintenance is amazing when ever you put a service in they come right away or next day.  When summer comes if you are black they require you to where your wrist band while others do not, when you call corporate about the issue nothing happens. so if you are looking for a place to just sleep and eat not a bad place but if your looking for a warm welcoming home. this is not the place they make you feel less than as if your not paying to live there

I was looking for places to bring my kids and I was actually investigating the local mall. I Googled the nearby rail trails and checked this one out. I'm glad I did!
I started at the beginning on Lincoln Street on Highland Street in Marlborough and ended just past the crossing  at Sasseville Way. Even with Tropical Storm Lee overhead, people were biking, jogging  and walking on the trail.
All of the trail is paved. It has access to a dirt trail as well as two other trails. Trash cans and benches are available. The information i kiosks don't have a map  but one did warn of ticks and invasive species of plants, none named Robert, and insects.
There are multiple street  crossings and not all of the buttons on the crossing lights work. Traffic did stop as I approached without touching the buttons.
What stood out to me was the flora and insects that I observed! All sorts of colorful wild  flowers  and it attracted pollinating insects such as  bees and even a monarch butterfly . I haven't seen many this year so it caught my attention. I did find a lot of English Oak tree acorns.
There was a small stream running along part of the trail. One area of the trail has a great view of the Assabet River!
There is a bike  repair station with tools and a manual air pump.
I didn't hear or see to many  birds. I did see   squirrels.
There are community contributions along the trail.
I am going to recommend this rail trail and I want to explore it in full!

I love that this rail trail has so much paved ground, it's something the other local ones are lacking and makes the world of difference when pushing a stroller. Great balance of sunny and shade on the trail, Porta potty available on trail if needed. Only downfall I found was the lack of designated parking lot.

As it currently exists, I'd give this trail 3 and a half stars. I gave it four because there is no half star option. So here is the good, bad and ugly of this trail with some caveats. First, starting at the Marlboro end, I rode a criterion type bike the length of the trail. This type frame I'd fast, maneurable, and known to give a hard ride. It has one inch wide tires to reduce friction and increase speed. Since the first 1 to 2 miles is down hill, it was a real rush. Without pedaling I was pushing 20 MPH most of the time. But use caution, on this hot July morning, there was moderate foot and bike traffic. There are also many road crossings which demand a full stop with dismount. One inch wheels don't like curb drops of any height. This is an urban trail but much of it is deeply shaded green stretches broken by road crossings. There is a lovely panoramic view about 3 miles into the ride. There are many quiet, shaded spots to stop with a friend for lunch. There are some age bumps as the pavement crosses the line into Hudson. Then pavement smoothes our nicely. Unfortunately there are several complicated crossings in Hudson, some are dangerous towards the last few miles. The areas of Broad St, Loring  and Vila Do Porto are difficult.  At one point I had to stop and go to the Trail Forks app to figure out where the trail resumes in the mass of Intersecting roads . A sign would help but there was none. Traffic crosses at perhaps 270 degrees here and the traffic lights help little as the pedestrian function is quite short. To make matters worse, there is some road construction in progress and there are some nasty uneven pavement in several places, remember, 1 inch wheels! In spite of the issues, ARRT is mostly a pleasant, fun ride. I hope at some point the difficult intersections can be modified. The drivers in the area were pleasant and courteous and often waived right of way.
Very beautiful trail that's almost completely flat, clean, and well maintained. Nice place for a stroll and pretty trees. A few short side trails that can be fun to poke around in.
It was a nice easy riding rail trail. The only downsides is there is lots of intersections to cross.

Lovely easy trail, mostly flat. Increased foot traffic in the evenings but for the most part it's mainly bicycles and there's enough room. Less than 300 ft elevation gain.My seven year old did this in 80+ minutes with some breaks.

Nice Trail for walking, running and bike riding. No motorized vehicles or electric vehicles allowed. Only handicapped scooters allowed. Those riding motorized vehicles will be reported to Law Enforcement.

This particular trail begins at Lincoln St. Marlborough and goes through Hudson continuing to almost the Hudson, Stow line.
This trail is for our community to enjoy. People of all ages are welcome. Anyone committing acts of vandalism to nearby property will be reported. Many properties have video surveillance. Any one witnesses a crime is encouraged to video tape it safely and reported to the Marlborough, PD. Be also alert for anyone getting injured. Offer assistance. UMass Marlborough Hospital is nearby at the End of Ash St and off of Hudson St. Hydrate as much as possible.

Be careful crossing streets. Wait for vehicles to stop for you. Do not ride bicycles across. Walk your bikes, be safe.

Be respectful of everyone! Enjoy the RailTrail.
Really nice trail.  Friendly people also walking. Just wish they had some benched.  We are handicapped and it would have been nice to sit. We would have been able to walk much further.

My son enjoyed this outing at Boundless adventures during the spring break. He went there with his 4 friends and all of them had a great time. He was definitely tired after the 3 hour hiatus but all worked out well as expected at the end of the day. The registration process was easy and navigating through the website was easy. This place is also located in Marlboro and we could go to the mall after . The kids ended up eating at the food court.
response_from_owner_text: Thanks Padma. We are so glad that your son and his group of friends enjoyed their visit. We hope to see you again soon!

review_text: My 14 yo son has done the half day camp the last 2 years and loves it. This year my 11 yo daughter did it too and also had a wonderful time. They both have very different climbing experience but the courses are challenging enough for comfortable climbers while also being reasonable for those newer to climbing.
response_from_owner_text: Thank you Brian. We are so glad to hear that your children enjoyed our summer program.

review_text: My son loved this camp!  His first day was pouring rain and even with unfavorable weather he came home full of smiles and stories.  His camp experience was fantastic from start to finish!  He asks to go back to this camp every year :) Thank you!
response_from_owner_text: Love it. Thank you Melissa.

review_text: My child had an awesome time at the 1/2 camp this summer. They hope to go back as soon as possible!
response_from_owner_text: Thank you Rebecca. We will be having an after school program as well which might work well for your child.

review_text: My kids love, love, loved this camp!
response_from_owner_text: Thank you Phaea. We hope to see your kids next summer!

review_text: The bunkers and the ponds were the highlights. Awesome weathered bunkers throughout the trails from WW2, ponds left and right with many birds. Beautiful views in the winter, can't wait to see them in the summer. It's a 8 mile hike if you do the whole loop. Definitely worth it. You can even see the old light and power line and poles from when people used to live in that land!

The birds were out. I saw some bird watchers. I heard a woodpecker and saw some ducks, etc. There was water over the trail so I didn't explore too much.

The Rice Tavern was interesting. The basement and stairs as well as the foundation remained. I might not have seen it if it weren't a PokeStop.

A great place for a hike, but buggy in the summer. I've been twice, both during the week, and it was practically deserted both times - perfect for anyone who wants some quiet. The disused ammunition bunkers are an interesting piece of local history.

Great area to explore old WWll grounds. Mostly flat with some old paved walkways. Lots of seemingly random paths that will take you all over the area. Perfect for a 30 minute walk or hours long exploration.

Excellent! The patrol road and white pond trail are very wide and open to hiking and biking. There's plenty of space to social distance and the majority of people I saw had masks ready or were wearing. Parking is free and plentiful at the entrance and visitor center. A lot of the patrol road is currently closed. Plenty of wetlands around and souvenirs of the time when it was an annex of Fort Devens. You can also make entrance to the Refuge from the Marlboro-Sudbury State Forest
The trails are large, well marked and paved in some cases.  It was a military installation so many paths are the width of a road.  Very casual-walk friendly.

I have been to this place one summer morning and had a very good experience. Away from the city noise, feel near to the nature. Being a weekday morning, there were a few people around. Spent an hour and Will come again to explore trails. Wish I lived nearby and come for the walk daily.
Excellent place for walking and fishing! The trails are easy for kids and has a very beautiful view!
Great old barn, nice entrance area with plenty of seating. Snack bar was open all weekend, locker rooms were plenty big, and the ice section is separate to keep the ice quality as good as possible.

The ice is PERFECT and the crowd is almost always moderate, and hence, suits both beginner as well as advanced skaters. Plus the staff are super super kind and helpful. Can't wait for the rink to open back again!
Great old school hockey game. Parking was tough, ice was in great shape. And canteen shop was open and had good service and popcorn
My grandkids and I had a blast. Just a wonderful time and all the people who made this day possible

Considering this rink is pretty old, it's not that bad. Good surface and benches, stands for fans and family. The locker rooms are a decent size. The locker room showers and related uncleanliness is the main reason for the 3 stars. There is literally orange gunk/residue on the shower walls since the showers are never cleaned. The paint is also chipping off the walls, and last time I was there, the locker room restroom shower door did not have a door handle, making it almost impossible to open.
It's gotten a lot better, more friendlier staff, great atmosphere for families in the community.
They do an excellent job on the ice with the Zamboni drivers I'm very consistent with the surface of the ice nice and smooth.
Pretty good rink. Only complaint is that there isn't much parking and it's difficult to get too

These's restroom and water fountain, and the door is usually open.

Learn to Sail

Learn-to-Sail classes are available to all Members of the MIT Community. In just a few hours, MITNA Learn to Sail classes will teach you how to sail!

If you have previous experience, show up to the "first" Mid-Week session (Class 1) to learn how the Pavilion works.

If you are new to sailing, register for the set of Mid-Week 1-2-3 sessions or for a Sunday session.
Gorgeous campus and area.
Cool view of the Boston skyline!

Amazing view of the Charles River and Boston's skyline from the terrace. I was there for an evening networking event (5:30 PM) in early May and, despite it being a sunny day, it was freezing because of the unrelenting wind. Bring a jacket with you and enjoy the view!
Our sailing pavilion from 1978 to 1980. We used to sail up and down Charles River. It was great to recently be back and see that our membership cars is still here. #drlepervanche_mit

Charles River Memorial Drive near MIT Sailing Pavillion is a get stop to see Boston at night or day. Great for pictures and walking, biking, running or romantic view.  Great for friends, family or special someone

One of the three best extracurriculars to try at MIT. Come on down! Super welcoming to all community members!

Offers a learn to sail program on the tech dinghies, then you can branch out to lasers, 420s, FJs, Lynx 19, sailboards, and more. Also serves institute research programs, e.g. with UAVs.

A small relaxing pavilion with old-time charm and the promise of adventure.  After taking introductory classes (which are quite popular), MIT affiliates can go sailing any time - even as alumni.  Windsurfing is also available, after an introductory course.  The pavilion is also a great place to host small gatherings and events with scenic river views.  Overall, an amazing resource nestled on the beautiful Charles!

It is the best place to watch the sunset. At sunset, you can see many people perched on the railings. In mid-May, you can see Harvard graduates posing for photos in their gowns. It is said that it is a tradition for graduates to jump off this bridge, but these days it seems to be forbidden. This bridge leads to the Harvard Business School campus. This is my favorite walking trail in the neighborhood.
One of the best sunset views in the city
Take a peaceful walk over the Charles river on the lovely and historic John Weeks Footbridge. Pause in reflections of life and light of Harvard shimmering across the gentle mirror of night.
The only footbridge on the Charles and definitely worth a special visit.
A few pictures from today's Dragon Boat Festival by the John W. Weeks Footbridge!
Nice park with some great festivals!

Great bridge to walk across on a sunrise or sunset. Really lovely during the spring, fall, and cool summer days. Perfect for people watching or seeing the Harvard crew teams practice. Walked across the bridge daily for two years and really enjoyed the views and serenity.
great meeting place, but the best time is dawn on May morning.
Nice park to take a walk or to have a picnic with family and friends.

Beautiful outdoor space; tons of free shows.
Music, dance, open mic, a capella, comedy, movie nights

Best kept secret for up close and personal performances.  Sun sets off to the side of the stage, just beyond the trees.  Short stroll to watch it over the Charles.  Can't wait for the 2023 schedule to come out.
Lovely outdoor performance space. Buggy at night, but that's to be expected.
Visited to see Glitter Boys for a dance party. Amphitheater has great acoustics. Lots of parking. Park personnel are helpful. Nice place to visit, experience Charles River.

Free shows to help provide a sense of community. Also good opportunity for volunteering with "Friends of Herter Park". (No bureaucratic hoops to jump through to start volunteering). Events include anything from open mic sessions to professional performances.
Lovely setting next to the Charles River, with comfortable seating.
Lovely park in the Charles that is physically larger in area than the Esplanade, with its own amphitheatre and roster of performances.

Nice views, but a little narrow and noisy since, um, it's not just pedestrians using the bridge. There are unobstructed views of the TD Center toward the south side.

For a more peaceful walk, try walking over the nearby locks just to the west.

What better way to overcome your fear of bridges than have your boyfriend drag you across one in the middle of winter...  Oh did I mention it's a grated bridge?  5 stars for the humor and beautiful view

I had to cross this bridge while walking The Freedom Trail. Couldn't look down. I did stop to take a photo of the Charles River. I just happened to spot the boat I would have been on if I didn't lose courage. lol
Also caught a sea gull taking a brake.
This bridge is completely rotten!!! Pathway unsafe - particularly for cyclists.
Can see nice harbor view of Boston from here.

We walked across the North Washington Street Bridge on our grand adventure in Boston. This Bridge is part of the Freedom trail that we followed and showed our daughter many historic places. The bridge itself always seems to be under some sort of construction but still, the bridge is a beautiful piece of the area.

Currently undergoing a major renovation after getting so old that the roadbed was literally wearing away. Thanks to the inept leadership of former MassDOT chief Stephanie Pollack, pedestrians and cyclists were, as usual, thought of last: there is a way-too-narrow walkway on the west side of the temporary bridge for pedestrians and cyclists to use. At the narrowest point, just before the stairs and the Converse building, the walkway is only 1.5 m wide!
Whoever did the pedestrian/cyclist counts while the old bridge was still open needs a few rounds of electroshock! First of all, you're combing what was TWO walkways of the old bridge (one on either side) into ONE, and then you have to take into account 1) Businesspeople walking going back and forth to work from Charlestown and the North End. 2) HUNDREDS of children and parents going back and forth from Charlestown to the two schools in the North End.  3) HUNDREDS of tourists who ALSO stop frequently mid-bridge to take picture and/or catch their breath. 4) Through commuters like myself on a bike where your options are to either mix it up with groups 1-3 or ride in traffic with NO SHOULDER across the bridge.
Let's hope the finished project "sometime in 2023" is true to its goal of providing ADEQUATE walking/cycling/bus lanes, but I'm certainly not holding my breath!
The Charlestown Bridge is the best location to use as a reference for direction in and out of Boston toward Haymarket through back roads.

place_name: Mass Audubon Magazine Beach Park Nature Center
review_text: This great resource is located in the beautiful, historic Powder Magazine -- the oldest standing building in the Charles River Basin (1818). We are very proud to have won a Cambridge Historical Commission Preservation Award in 2022 for restoring this landmark.

place_name: Mass Audubon Magazine Beach Park Nature Center
review_text: Nicely repurposed building with good historical interpretation. Enjoyed the plantings and the river front walk.

place_name: Mass Audubon Magazine Beach Park Nature Center
review_text: A pleasant surprise & long overdue. Gteat location

place_name: EscapeTrails - Outdoor Escape Game - Scavenger Hunt - Amazing Race
review_text: This was a unique and special way to kick off our combined bachelor/bachelorette party with team bride vs team groom on a scavenger hunt throughout Boston! They made it easy for us to personalize certain challenges to make it feel extra fun and special. Would definitely recommend!

place_name: EscapeTrails - Outdoor Escape Game - Scavenger Hunt - Amazing Race
review_text: We booked the Boston specific EscapeTrail for a work outing - Easy to book, the organizers were very kind and we had a great time. It is just the perfect combination of figuring out how the game works, walking to different locations to collect infos and items, competing between the teams, funny sidequests and games, cool facts about Boston, and a great storyline. We have seen so many new places and learned a lot, and had lots of fun. A perfect outdoor adventure. We finished in about three hours after a very fast paced game, but it could also be played all day (with breaks in between). Would totally book another adventure!
response_from_owner_text: Glad you enjoyed your EscapeTrails experience and look forward to you booking your next EscapeTrails adventure.

review_text: Our work group had a great time. Coordinating our needs/preferences with Mark and co. was easy and they kept up with our teams throughout our hunt. We'd absolutely recommend EscapeTrails. Thanks for a great experience!
response_from_owner_text: So glad you guys had a great time.  Hope your food was nice after!

Excellent studio - the CEO Don basically gives you everything you could ever need for a commercial shoot- photography shoot and especially great for rental space .

review_text: One of the better sound stages in the Boston area.

review_text: 5 stars and more
